On August 15, 2012, FCS engineers provtcled reasonabte assurance that the indication was incorrect and that the sluice gates were cfosed. FCS does not have a 15 delineating sluice gate operability. The functionality determination requlre(t that divers confirm that the sluice gates were closed. On Augu,st 25,2012, divers documented the following gaps between the sluice gate bottom edge and the

On August 25, 2012, divers removed the sediment from all sluice gate bottoms and a 3-inch tree branch from CW-14E, retuming the sluice gates' capabHity to be fuUy closed in the event of a design basis flood.

On September 11,2012, this event was determined to be reportable under 10 CFR 70.73(a)(2)(v)(B), any event or condition that could have prevented the fulfiDment of the safety function of structures or systems that are needed to remove residual heat.
LICENSEE EVENT REPORT (LEA) U.s. NUCLEAR REGULATORY COMMISSION

The apparent cause Of the failure of the sluice gates to fully close was debris under the gates. Acause analysis is in-process and when completed. this LER wiD be supplemented to include any additional causes that are identified.
Apreventive maintenance activity was previously created to cycle CW-14A1B1CIDIEIF through their
fuJI range of travel in ensure availability for flood mitigation. This activity is currently perfonned
monthly and is perfonned to ensure the sluice gates perform their safety function.
A flood impairment has been placed in the control room to provide direction for verifying fun closure
and flushing sediment and debris that could prevent the gates from fully closing during a design
Acause analysis is in-process and when completed, this LER wiD be supplemented to include any additional corrective actions.

The loss of the ability to close the intake structure sluice gates during flood conditions could lead to the loss of the raw water pumps which supply cooling water component cooling water heat exchangers. The raw water system also prOvides direct cooling for the folowing safety related components in the event that the component cooling water system is unavailable: the shutdown cooling heat exchangers. the highllow pressure safety injection pump bearing oil and seal coolers. the containment spray pump bearing oit and seal coolers. and the control room air conditioners.
In the event of a DBA. the component cooling water system is designed to provide sufficient cooling water to the engineered safeguards equipment.
This event does result In a safety system functional failure In accordance with NEI-99'()2.
A cause analysi$ is in-process and when completed. this LER will be supplemented to include any previous events that are identified .
